bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Florence M. Read, February 21, 1922

div1.p: Hanson describes the work of the sanitary campaign against yellow fever in Peru, naming physicians and surveyors.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Florence M. Read, February 21, 1922
div1.opener:
DIRECTOR GENERAL
HENRY HANSON
M. D.
BAJO LOS AUSPICIOS DEL
GOBIERNO PERUANO Y LA
JUNTA INTERNACIONAL DE
SANIDAD DE ROCKEPELLER
FOUNDATION
Campaña Sanitaria contra la Fiebre Amarilla en el Perú
OFICINA CENTRAL
AVENIDA PIEROLA 545 -- TELEFONO 3428
LIMA -- PERU
February 21, 1922.
NUMERO
Miss Florence M. Read,
Assistant Secretary,
The International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York City.
My dear Miss Read:
div1.p:
Your letter of 28Ultm was received yesterday
in which I note that you think it proper to allow a months
pay to certain employeed who have served a year in the Cam-
paign, but at the same time you do not think that Mr. Seeley
should be considered under the same ruling. It appears to
me that Mr. Seely should be considered under the same con-
ditions as he will have had a full years service, and has
done exceptionally hard work, and his trip to Panama and back
was necessary to enable him to continue. He is a man with a
family and consequently has heavier expenses than the single
men and on the basis of what is allowed for the others (a
limited number of them) it is my opinion that he should be
allowed one month without regard to what will be the outcome
of his relationship with the Panama Canal Government. His
work in the Department of Lambayeque has meant a great deal
in the successful outcome of the campaign, and he was sub-
jected to a very heavy expense on account of his coming back
to continue for the few remaining months.

Dr. Caballero, Mr. Dunn and Sr. Olivari have about com-
pleted their survey of the coast to the south and I am happy
to report that so far they have found nothing in the line of
suspicious illness. The Stegomya index however is very high,
running about 50$ of more. The lowest index which they found
was in Moquegua and Ilo, where it was about 25$. Dr. Caballero
reports that they have been very well received and that the
authorities have accepted them and their mission seriously.

Mr. Corrigan has just come in from the north Lima and
Ancash sections and states that they are having great diffi-
culty in securing fish on account of the flooding of the
streams and ditches due to rains and melting snows in the
mountains. Notwithstanding this we are keeping the index
down even in this more or less superficially worked sector.
I presume that I underestimated the need for fish as I thought
that a half million would meet our needs, but as it turned out
we used more than 800,000, up to the end of the year 1921. In
the distribution sheet which we are sending Mr. Kirk we show
a trifle over 700,000 which represents what was bought at so
much per thousand, the rest was secured through fishermen who
were working on a daily wage.

I am very glad to have the extract from the letter
of Dr. W.B. Caldwell to Mr. Le Prince. It is interesting to
his remarks as to importation cases. Where do these impor-
tation cases come from? It appears that they have some
focus nearby where the disease is kept up. If we had such
an occurrence here we would be afraid that a sort of “vicious
circle” might be started by which we would have a long drawn
out smoldering epidemic or endemic which after a while would
manifest itself in a new sharp outbreak unles the Stegomya
work were kept up sufficiently long for these other places
immunize themselves.

Although we are now in the midst of the summer season
and are having the hottest weather of the summer we have not
yet had any reports of suspicious cases. I am “knocking on
wood” and confidently hoping that we will have no more.

Some time ago I sent you a brief preliminary report
of our work, and have been wondering if my estimates were
exaggerated. Dr. Quiroz who was in Ferreñafe and in other
sections of the Campaign with me was in the Office yesterday
and we discussed these matters and he stated that he did not
think that I had exaggerated the thing beyond what actually
did happen. It is a pity we were not more thoroughly organ-
ized from the start so as to enable us to have gotten more
acurate statistics during the crisis of the epidemic.

We are doing what we can to get all our data togather
but it is slow work and there is a great deal of it.

Trusting that we shall have no further occasion to
send you bad news, I am,
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Henry Hanson, M.D.,
